Flying Penguins
I loved my job working at NASA in the fiber optics research branch. I was an engineer.
But at NASA you can’t escape space and one day a coworker told me I should apply to be an astronaut. He thought I had “the right stuff.” I did not think so.
Me? An astronaut? Who becomes an astronaut? Not guys like me.
But another coworker applied and was accepted. He was short and stocky and built more like a professional boxer than an astronaut.
If he can do it, I thought, so can I. I decided to try. Even then it took me another year to apply.
Then came the waiting. The interview process can be really long when 2,500 people apply for 25 positions! After almost a year, I was still in the running.
Maybe, I thought, I do have “the right stuff.”
One sunny morning in June of 1998 my research team finished making the first fiber sensors EVER. It was an exciting day! We were all happy and celebrating.
Then someone handed me a message to call Ken “Taco” Cockrell, Chief of the Astronaut Office. And I knew. I just knew. My whole life was about to change.
I instantly thought of the dramatic stories astronauts tell when asked the question, “Where were you when you got “THE CALL?”
“On a mountain top, in a submarine, at war….”
…in the middle of the most exciting day ever being a NASA engineer….I thought.
I called Taco back immediately. But the call got dropped.
I called again. The call failed.
Uh oh. Not a good sign, I thought
I took a breath and dialed the number for a third time. Taco picked up on the third ring.
“Leland, how’s it going?” he asked.
Small talk, I thought. He’s letting me down easy.
“Fine, Ken. How are you?”
There was a long pause that felt like an eternity.
“I’m calling to tell you that we’d like you to be part of the 1998 Astronaut Corps. Do you want to be part of the Astronaut Corps?”
This moment was different from anything else I had experienced. I could barely contain my excitement.
WOW, I’m an astronaut candidate! Okay, I’m ready. Let’s go!
I said, “YES!”
“Great. Now don’t tell anybody.”
I sat alone in my office. I’d just heard the most life-changing news ever—and I couldn’t tell a soul.
I couldn’t do it. This news was just too big. My friends at NASA would have to keep a secret. I shared the news with my team.
Then I called my parents.
My mother told me she loved me and was proud of me. A lot of prayer would be coming as she thought about the risk and danger.

When I talked to my Dad I couldn’t help but get emotional. I thought about all the lessons he had taught me. I thought about vision, teamwork, and the projects we had done. I heard his words of wisdom, words I had written as part of my application essay, “Work hard, have fun, and share the ball.”
I was so proud to tell him the news. His son was going to be an astronaut.
My father usually had lots to say, but that day, he was quiet. He was too proud for words.
And for once I was too excited to say nothing. I had a new dream. I was going to reach the stars.
